questions.question: What is CSS used for?
options: Styling HTML elements
Creating interactive web pages
Writing JavaScript code
Structuring web content
questions.answer: Styling HTML elements

questions.question: How do you link an external CSS file to an HTML document?
options: <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
<script src="style.css"></script>
<style src="style.css"></style>
<css file="style.css"></css>
questions.answer: <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">

questions.question: What are the three main types of CSS selectors?
options: Element, class, and ID
Tag, attribute, and style
Head, body, and div
Inline, internal, and external
questions.answer: Element, class, and ID

questions.question: What is the box model in CSS?
options: A way to style text
A way to create rounded corners
A model that describes the layout of an element
A model for creating responsive designs
questions.answer: A model that describes the layout of an element

questions.question: What is the difference between inline, block, and inline-block display?
options: Inline elements are displayed horizontally, block elements vertically, and inline-block elements are a mix of both.
Inline elements are displayed vertically, block elements horizontally, and inline-block elements are a mix of both.
Inline elements are displayed horizontally, block elements horizontally, and inline-block elements are vertically.
Inline elements are displayed vertically, block elements vertically, and inline-block elements are horizontally.
questions.answer: Inline elements are displayed horizontally, block elements vertically, and inline-block elements are a mix of both.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to change the font size of an element?
options: font-style
font-weight
font-size
font-family
questions.answer: font-size

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to set the background color of an element?
options: background-color
color
bg-color
background
questions.answer: background-color

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to add padding around an element?
options: margin
border
padding
space
questions.answer: padding

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to align text within an element?
options: text-align
align-text
text-position
align
questions.answer: text-align

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to create rounded corners?
options: border-radius
corner-radius
rounded-corners
curve-corners
questions.answer: border-radius

questions.question: What is the CSS Flexbox model used for?
options: Creating responsive layouts
Styling text
Adding animations
Creating complex tables
questions.answer: Creating responsive layouts

questions.question: What is the CSS Grid Layout model used for?
options: Creating responsive layouts
Styling text
Adding animations
Creating complex tables
questions.answer: Creating responsive layouts

questions.question: What is the difference between absolute and relative positioning?
options: Absolute positioning positions an element relative to its parent, while relative positioning positions it relative to its normal position.
Relative positioning positions an element relative to its parent, while absolute positioning positions it relative to its normal position.
Absolute positioning positions an element relative to the viewport, while relative positioning positions it relative to its parent.
Relative positioning positions an element relative to the viewport, while absolute positioning positions it relative to its parent.
questions.answer: Absolute positioning positions an element relative to its parent, while relative positioning positions it relative to its normal position.

questions.question: What is the z-index property used for?
options: To control the stacking order of elements
To set the opacity of elements
To create rounded corners
To add shadows to elements
questions.answer: To control the stacking order of elements

questions.question: What is the difference between margin and padding?
options: Margin adds space outside an element, while padding adds space inside an element.
Padding adds space outside an element, while margin adds space inside an element.
Margin and padding both add space outside an element.
Margin and padding both add space inside an element.
questions.answer: Margin adds space outside an element, while padding adds space inside an element.

questions.question: What is a CSS selector?
options: A keyword used to style elements
A rule for specifying which HTML elements to style
A property used to change the appearance of elements
A value used to set the style of elements
questions.answer: A rule for specifying which HTML elements to style

questions.question: What is the specificity of a CSS selector?
options: The order in which the selector is defined
The importance of the selector
The number of selectors in the rule
The combination of selectors, IDs, classes, and elements
questions.answer: The combination of selectors, IDs, classes, and elements

questions.question: What is the cascade in CSS?
options: The order in which CSS rules are applied
The way CSS rules are inherited
The way CSS rules are combined
The way CSS rules are prioritized
questions.answer: The order in which CSS rules are applied

questions.question: What is the difference between a class selector and an ID selector?
options: Class selectors can be used multiple times, while ID selectors can only be used once.
ID selectors can be used multiple times, while class selectors can only be used once.
Class selectors are more specific than ID selectors.
ID selectors are more specific than class selectors.
questions.answer: Class selectors can be used multiple times, while ID selectors can only be used once.

questions.question: What is the `*` selector used for?
options: To select all elements on the page
To select the first element of a certain type
To select the last element of a certain type
To select elements with a specific attribute
questions.answer: To select all elements on the page

questions.question: What is a CSS pseudo-class?
options: A keyword added to a selector to style elements based on their state
A keyword added to a selector to style specific parts of an element
A keyword added to a selector to create animations
A keyword added to a selector to create responsive designs
questions.answer: A keyword added to a selector to style elements based on their state

questions.question: What is a CSS pseudo-element?
options: A keyword added to a selector to style elements based on their state
A keyword added to a selector to style specific parts of an element
A keyword added to a selector to create animations
A keyword added to a selector to create responsive designs
questions.answer: A keyword added to a selector to style specific parts of an element

questions.question: Which pseudo-class is used to style an element when the mouse hovers over it?
options: :hover
:active
:focus
:visited
questions.answer: :hover

questions.question: Which pseudo-element is used to style the first letter of an element?
options: ::first-letter
::first-child
::before
::after
questions.answer: ::first-letter

questions.question: Which pseudo-element is used to style the first line of an element?
options: ::first-line
::first-child
::before
::after
questions.answer: ::first-line

questions.question: What is a CSS preprocessor?
options: A tool that compiles CSS code into HTML
A tool that minifies CSS code
A tool that adds dynamic features to CSS
A tool that extends the syntax of CSS
questions.answer: A tool that extends the syntax of CSS

questions.question: What is the CSS `flex-wrap` property used for?
options: To wrap flex items to the next line when there's not enough space in the container.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To wrap flex items to the next line when there's not enough space in the container.

questions.question: What is the CSS `flex-direction` property used for?
options: To set the main axis of a flex container to be row or column.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To set the main axis of a flex container to be row or column.

questions.question: What is the CSS `flex-basis` property used for?
options: To set the initial size of a flex item.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To set the initial size of a flex item.

questions.question: What is the CSS `flex-grow` property used for?
options: To specify how much a flex item should grow relative to other flex items.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To specify how much a flex item should grow relative to other flex items.

questions.question: What is the CSS `flex-shrink` property used for?
options: To specify how much a flex item should shrink relative to other flex items.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To specify how much a flex item should shrink relative to other flex items.

questions.question: What is the CSS `flex` shorthand property used for?
options: To combine the `flex-grow`, `flex-shrink`, and `flex-basis` properties into a single declaration.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To combine the `flex-grow`, `flex-shrink`, and `flex-basis` properties into a single declaration.

questions.question: What is the CSS `order` property used for?
options: To change the order of flex items within the flex container.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
questions.answer: To change the order of flex items within the flex container.

questions.question: What is the CSS `align-self` property used for?
options: To override the alignment of a single flex item.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
questions.answer: To override the alignment of a single flex item.

questions.question: What is the CSS `justify-self` property used for?
options: To override the justification of a single flex item.
To align flex items along the main axis.
To align flex items along the cross axis.
To distribute extra space between flex items.
questions.answer: To override the justification of a single flex item.

questions.question: What is the CSS `gap` shorthand property used for?
options: To set the gap between rows and columns in a CSS Grid layout.
To set the gap between flex items in a CSS Flexbox layout.
Both of the above.
None of the above.
questions.answer: Both of the above.

questions.question: What is the CSS `z-index` property used for?
options: To control the stacking order of elements.
To set the opacity of elements.
To create rounded corners.
To add shadows to elements.
questions.answer: To control the stacking order of elements.

questions.question: What is the CSS `opacity` property used for?
options: To set the transparency of an element.
To create rounded corners.
To add shadows to elements.
To create gradients.

options: To add shadows to elements.
To create rounded corners.
To set the transparency of elements.
